Fields.DialogueText: ... And we have a winner!
And I get my Suggestion Box back finally.
Good idea, asking the crew to come up with names for the cat. This crew can certainly be creative.
Who knew? So did you participate?

Fields.MenuText: Nah. She's your cat, so I felt the final choice should be yours.
I think preparing the finalist list should count as participating... but yes, I cast my vote. The ones left all had their charm though, so it was a tough choice.
No. We're talking about a cat here. You can call her whatever you want and she still won't come.

Fields.DialogueText: You said it yourself, Capt'n. Even after you pared the list down, the crew suggested some really fun ones that I would never have thought of.
Didn't they?
But that's one of the things I admire about cats, Capt'n. And we can't keep calling her ‘that cat' forever, you know.
So, from now on I should call her... what?
Gin Fizz!
Fizz. Short and easy to say... yes, that does sound like a winner.
For Seaman Zehner it definitely is... he gets the shore pass for coming up with it. I'll tell him the news later, though. Right now I spy a nearby Morgana.
@BATTLE
Relax, New Orleans. You often tell me not to stress the crew, but right now the one wound too tight is you.
I can't help it, Capt'n. I always feel like a mother hen when we're on these escort missions.
It's bad enough when their Belle is up and about, but ones like this... she's seen better days.
We'll get 'em there safely.
Can she manage cruising speed, or will even that be too much?
The more we push, the more strain on the boilers. Flank speed is out of the question.

Fields.MenuText: Wanting her to go fast doesn't make her go any faster.
Easy does it. If she breaks before we get her to safety, it's all for nothing.
We have to push as hard as we can. Speed is life.

Fields.DialogueText: Yeah.
I think tickling would work... if I only knew where she was sensitive...
*wink* You'd be amazed how effective my tongue lashes can be for that, Capt'n...
I wish she'd look alive. We've got company, Capt'n.
@BATTLE
Okay, if the Chief has signed off on the turbine business, then I think the next matter on the table is...
Something rubbing against my leg.
Fizz? What are you doing over there?

Fields.MenuText: Oh well. At attention folks, Cat on the Bridge!
Ship's pet or not, Fizz, you're not part of the bridge crew. Off you go, before someone steps on you.
Curiosity killed the cat, Fizz. Unless we have rats chewing on the wires up here, you don't have run of the ship... Shoo!

Fields.DialogueText: You should probably make that Kitten on the Bridge, Capt'n. Cat and Capt'n sound too much alike.
*Listen to the Capt'n, Fizz... there's nothing here to see...*
Don't be mean, Capt'n. Curiosity killed the cat, but satisfaction brought it back. ... Oops...
New Orleans?
He he he... imagine seeing you here...
Wait. Were you there the whole time?
Was I where the whole time?
In the corner. ... that Gin Fizz was so interested in...
If I said yes?
I know cats are rumored to see spirits, but that was too uncanny.
I... just came over here to check on what she was interested in...
You don't say.
*grin* I just remembered that I have somewhere that I have to be...
Well, well. The plot thickens.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Hey, NO Boat! I've got good news!
Doc Sutter?
...*ixnay, ocDay... *
Well? What's going on here?
Quite simple, Captain. The last time NO Boat visited sick bay, she surprised me and I knocked over some glassware.
I see.
Ah, nothing that can't be replaced.
We can work with it, so don't worry, NO Boat.
Really, Doc? That's such a relief to hear. Well, I won't hold you up...
Just a moment, Doctor. I have a few questions.
... Drat.
I'm curious what repurposed medical glassware would be useful for... especially when New Orleans is involved.
Wouldn't want to bore you with the particulars, Captain...
Doc, If you're in on something with New Orleans, I'm sure the last thing I need to worry about is being bored.

Fields.MenuText: She's trying to set up a distillery, isn't she?
Let me guess... she wants toys for playing make-believe.
I'm guessing it's something to do with a "hair of the dog" therapy.

Fields.DialogueText: What a wonderful idea, Capt'n! Why didn't I think of that before?
*wink* I've always wanted to play doctor...
No, but if the doc could make singing a prescribed cure for the blues, it would help me convince more people to join the Jazz Revue.
The jig is up, Doc. Let Doc Sutter off the hook, okay? This was all my idea, not his.
Not a chance, NO Boat. We were in cahoots, Captain.
*ALARM*
Looks like you both get a chance to reflect on your answers.
@BATTLE
Before you rake Doc Sutter over the coals, Capt'n, let me explain.
I'm listening...
First, what do you know about absinthe, Capt'n?
You mean the green spirit derived from wormwood and anise or fennel, used by French army doctors in the 1850s to prevent fevers and treat dysentery?
... You spoke to Doc first.
He spoke to me. From what he says, the proper way to prepare it is to dilute it by slowly adding ice water over a cube of sugar in a sieve--
And magic is made, Capt'n. The aroma... the transformation...
The fact that it is banned?
Only in the United States of America, Brazil, France, Belgium, the Netherlands, Germany and Italy...
I blame the damn teetotalers. And the French winemakers...
I mean, after the phylloxera infestation made cognac and champagne scarce, what else were people supposed to drink? Water?
Morganas aside, there's something wrong with the world when I have to go halfway around it to get a proper sazerac... a cocktail invented in the Big Easy!

Fields.MenuText: What happened to bourbon milk punch?
Even if it's banned in continental Europe and the United States, I think halfway around the world is exaggerating just a bit.
Is it true then that... absinthe makes the heart grow fonder?

Fields.DialogueText: It may be a classic, but even bourbon milk would become boring if I drank the same thing all the time.
... Okay, maybe not halfway. But it sure feels like it, sometimes.
Auughhhh! My ears, Capt'n.
You went to the doctor looking to jerry-rig a water drip. I don't understand why a pitcher of water wouldn't accomplish the same thing.
It's harder to control the rate that way. Slower is better. It's a drink that puts on a performance, Capt'n. A show to savor.
Besides, a carafe only fixes one drink at a time. It might not be a fountain, but several drippers could go at once, meaning no one has to wait.
How thoughtful. I guess you won't be hosting any drink parties anytime soon... since you're out of luck with the drip idea.
You won't allow it.
*ALARM*
No, you wouldn't like it.
Of course, because... hold on. Because I wouldn't like it?
@BATTLE
You've kept me in suspense long enough, Capt'n. What do you mean when you say I wouldn't like the drip?
Well, Doc showed me the contraption.
If proper absinthe preparation is as much about the performance as you say, then you wouldn't be happy with the aesthetics of that performance.
That bad?
How does like a patient etherized upon a table sound to you?
Not good. But...
But what?
I'm still surprised. I thought you'd be against the idea because it's for absinthe and la fée verte is a no-no.
I'm not happy about that. But absinthe isn't the only drink that clouds up and pastis, raki, sambucha and ouzo aren't banned.
So, how would I know the difference between say, a glass of herbsaint - which isn't a problem - and a glass of absinthe, which is?
Well, I could tell you, but... I see your point.

Fields.MenuText: As far as I can tell, societies don't fare better under temperance movements and don't collapse when prohibition is repealed. I don't see why it would be different here.
It would probably be prudent to refrain from flaunting my ignorance, though. Are we agreed, New Orleans?
Worst case scenario, I'm sure bottles of the stuff aren't easy to come by and would be useful to trade with.

Fields.DialogueText: You said it, Capt'n! I bet someday everyone will recognise how overblown absinthe's sinister reputation is and even the green fairy will be able to come out of hiding again.
That I shouldn't brag about it around dry sea lawyers? Aye aye, Capt'n!
I might have better sources to the good stuff than most...
At the very least, if there's ever a dysentery problem, we're set. And don't worry, Capt'n. I'll be responsible.
That goes without saying. You haven't let me down before, so I see no difference with this.
... And speaking of responsibility...
@BATTLE
Milk doesn't work. Hopefully the catnip...
"Hopefully the catnip" will what, New Orleans?
Whyyy... hello there, Capt'n! Did I say catnip? I meant ... catnap. Yes, catnap.
Catnap. Because...
Right. I was just talking to our supply officer here. About how tired she's been lately... due to her dog watches.
And... she has trouble falling asleep. So I suggested warm milk...
NO Boat...
Hold on a minute, I'm just getting warmed up here.
Be my guest.
Right. So, she told me she'd tried that already and it didn't work. I was about to suggest she try to nap with Fizz. A nap with a cat...
A catnap.
That's the idea, Capt'n.
While the cat is napping, I presume. And not in a catnip-induced stupor.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose you're going to tell me that Fizz has insomnia, too, so in order for Lieutenant Wills to actually nap with a catnapping cat, catnip is needed.
I'm almost afraid to ask how you got hold of catnip way out here.
You've outdone yourself, New Orleans. That is the most ridiculous explanation I've ever heard.

Fields.DialogueText: Now that's a tongue twister if I ever heard one, Capt'n. So... yes. What you said... I think.
From Doc Sutter, actually. He has a supply to make catnip tea, for... er... insomnia...
*grin* You're too kind, Capt'n. But if you think that one is ridiculous, just wait. I've got a million of them!
And the Lieutenant can't just drink the tea herself because...
Because I forgot why we had it in the first place?
I don't think anyone's going to get any naps right now, though.
@BATTLE
Okay, New Orleans. You have to stop with the catnip.
The wardroom smells minty and several officers have almost stepped on Fizz.
It works? Oh, good! Doc said not all cats respond to catnip. Now I can be sure...
Be sure of what?

Fields.MenuText: That Fizz high on catnip is still better than a drunken sailor?
That the rest of us aren't cats?
That Gin Fizz and catnip don't mix?

Fields.DialogueText: *wink* Oh I don't know about that, Capt'n. I can think of a lot of things to do with a drunken sailor... early in the morning!
Of course not, Capt'n. Even sailors vomit, but I've yet to see one hack up a hairball.
I'm sure they can mix, Capt'n. The question is whether the flavor is so different that it becomes a new concoction.
But seriously. You came up with that wild, unfounded idea that Fizz could see me even when no one else can. But I've been told cats have a good sense of smell too...
So the catnip is to cover your scent. What's the verdict?
I don't know. I haven't tried sneaking around her yet.
This I've got to see...
Then after you, Capt'n.
Let me get the hatch first... there. Fizz? Where... there you are. And just how did you get up to there? Are you stuck, or... hey!
Saved by the turret. Take my word for it, Capt'n, Gin Fizz has some serious hooks.
I think it's looking pretty official, New Orleans. Unless you moved your turret on purpose, Fizz saw you well enough to aim for it.
I'm glad you've learned to be considerate and look before you leap, Fizz. I'm not sure I like you finding me so easily, though.
Giving up so soon? That's unusual.
Don't worry, I'm just getting started in the Cat Deception and Distraction department. Except... how is she doing that?
It's the first time I've seen a cat that could see spirits, so you've got me. If I looked at the world through cat eyes I might have some insight, but...
The world through cat eyes... hmmm.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
That's quite the book there.
Concealing-Coloration in the Animal Kingdom - An Exposition of the Laws of Disguise Through Color and Pattern?
Yup. When in doubt, nature is full of concealment tips and tricks, Capt'n.

Fields.MenuText: So how does Mother Nature recommending you hide a 588-foot steel ship?
So you're something of a master of the art of disguise?
That said, why do you go au naturel every chance you get? You conceal less that way, not more...

Fields.DialogueText: According to the authors, the same way she recommends just about everything else.
There's just as much science to it as there is art, Capt'n. ... Or at least, it works better when the artists and scientists work together.
*wink* That's called misdirection, Capt'n. I get most eyes looking where I want them to, and not at where they could or should be.
Not that the book has all the answers. "All creatures have the shapes and colors they do just to blend into their surroundings?" Doubtful.
They don't?
Skunks aren't black and white just to infiltrate ostrich conventions, Capt'n.
Good Point. So, what's got you back to the basics on disguise?
The sleepwalkers in the fleet.
Standard Navy Gray #5 everywhere vertical and #20 Deck Gray for the horizontals may be enough for peacetime, but it doesn't do a damn against Morganas.
The non-Belle ships do need all the help they can get. Well, if anyone would know how to camouflage them, it would be you.
I only wish I did, Capt'n. But, I've got myself thinking. The guys who did this book were describing nature as they saw it. They were using the Mark I Eyeball, just like everyone else.
What if the Morgana Eyeball Mark I sees the world differently?
@BATTLE
Ask them. They're right over there.
Just what does a lady need to do to get Morgana peepers around here?
I did ask nicely...
And then you threatened to blow her head off and take them yourself.
If her looks could kill, I'd have been in trouble.
Well, that's one thing that humans, Belles and Morganas have in common, at least. I still fail to see exactly why you're so keen on how Morganas perceive things, though.
Let me put it this way, Capt'n. I can find a Morgana lurking without seeing her, right?
Right...
I still don't go toe-to-toe with a Morgana blindfolded.

Fields.MenuText: Good point. Knowing you, though, you've thought about how to pull it off.
And I thank you from the bottom of my heart that you don't. Please keep it that way.
I certainly wouldn't want you to either. She'd be a bad dance partner to begin with and a lousy one with her eyes covered up.

Fields.DialogueText: *grin* I sure have, Capt'n. I just can't find another Belle willing to help me test it.
*grin* I haven't met a Morgana yet that I wanted to give a handicap.
*grin* I couldn't have said it better myself, Capt'n.
Right. So, if Morganas are similar to you Belles, they still rely on their eyesight. What good does knowing that do?
If we knew for sure, there's no end to the optical illusions the camoufleurs over in the Bureau of Ships could cook up just to confuse Morganas.
And that kind of razzle dazzle wouldn't be limited to just Belle ships.
Right!
Still... you do know there are other ways to figure how well the Morganas see than spooning one's eyeball out of her skull, like... how did you put it, again?
*grin* An olive out of a jar.
That was an image I really didn't need, you know.
Sorry.
@BATTLE
Capt'n! Capt'n! Are the orders true?
What orders would that be, New Orleans?
The ones we just got, Capt'n! Did you really volunteer me to help with Morgana Perception research?
News travels fast. I told you there were ways beside dissection to test the Morganas' eyesight. We have first-hand experience with them, after all, which folks in the lab don't.
And since we haven't found a Morgana willing to drop by a lab without trying to destroy it first, someone has to bring the experiments to them. How does that sound to you?
It sounds like a dream come true. I always wanted to help with camouflage trials.
And when I hear the older Belles describe the paint jobs they got during the Great War... a "flock of sea-going Easter eggs"? I can't wait!

Fields.MenuText: Sea-going eggs... that might explain why they were having trouble getting volunteers. I'm starting to have second thoughts, myself.
I'd better radio ahead, then. It sounds like they're going to need all the paint they can get their hands on.
You may be jealous now, but I don't want to hear any complaints about what the rest of the fleet thinks.

Fields.DialogueText: Too late to get cold feet now, Capt'n. As for me, I'll try anything once...
I'd better press my smock, too!
Sorry, Capt'n, but the only ones who have the right to complain about me are standing on my decks. Anyone else is begging for trouble... if not from me, then from my crew.
Never mind that now, Capt'n. We've got work to do!
@BATTLE
*wink* Twice if I like it, three times to make sure and four times just to be on the safe side.
Capt'n... behold!
Now this is a paint measure! What do you think of a paint job like this? Like the bright color scheme for my hull?
I don't know...

Fields.MenuText: It doesn't seem conspicuous enough. Maybe a marquee?
You're sure this did any good last war?
I thought the idea was to make it hard to tell our course and speed, not how sober we were when last in port.

Fields.DialogueText: Too much to maintain. Sequins, on the other hand...
Oh, sure! Haven't you ever heard about the Battle of Barataria Bay, where a whole enemy battalion mistook a circus tent at high tide for a dreadnaught?
And this is just topside, Capt'n. Wait until you get an eyeful below deck!
Tell me you're kidding.
*grin* I'm kidding. So, which do you consider my better side? Port and Starboard are different patterns you know...
I know better than to answer that question, New Orleans. I'm a little worried about how well the deck crew accepts the new look, though.
A paint job this complex will be a tough one to keep up.
Don't worry, Capt'n. I'm working on some plans that'll give the crew an incentive.
Now I'm more than a little worried.
Hee hee hee.
@BATTLE
So this is what you meant by incentive for the paint crew. How is a live jazz dock party all that different from the norm, New Orleans?
We don't get to borrow a piano in every port.
You know what I mean.
Most sailors usually go in search of a party as soon as we hit the docks. Looking to find interesting places and interesting company.
More like looking to find places where the people are interested in company.
*wink* Not that it's the only way to dance, but it does take two to tango, Capt'n...
I'm well aware. I'm not seeing the link to our paint, though.
Think about how intimidating a warship can be. And drab.
That's something we currently can't be accused of... but I see your point. Between the music and the cubist backdrop...
Right here is the most adventurous and lively place in town! Let the resident thrill-seekers come to us, get to meet the eligible swabbies...

Fields.MenuText: That, plus the irresistibility of a sailor in uniform... and the rest is history. my hat is off to you, New Orleans.
Which spares the sailor's time hunting a receptive guide. Very clever.
We're certainly a novelty for the curious, whether we want to be or not.

Fields.DialogueText: *grin* Just doing my part to make sure everyone has a good time.
It's easy to motivate someone when they can see the rewards.
*grin* I may not be rigged for it, but right now I'm probably the biggest icebreaker in the fleet! Socially, at least.
Riiiiight. Well, carry on then.
Aye aye, Capt'n! You don't need to tell me twice!
Now all I need is to convince a couple more folks that they really do have talent. If even the Big Easy Revue could get a breather between sets, the party really could last until dawn!
The Protection Fleet is just trying to help, Capt'n!
Don't defend them, New Orleans. It's a known deal that Morganas spew that obnoxious mist, and that it coats everything.
The goons from the lab should know by now that post-engagement procedures include clean up. If the stuff we're using strips the paint along with it, then the paint's no good!
Apparently, it's the Protection Fleet's new stuff... but I'll admit that they could have tested it in the lab first...
You mean should have. Otherwise, we're looking at repainting after every Morgana fight. How is that practical?
Okay, okay. At least they'll hear about it before they get the fleet too invested in it. Maybe they have an idea for something that cleans better...

Fields.MenuText: If they kept a little tidbit like that to themselves, I will not be amused.
So in addition to keeping the seas clear of Morganas and camouflage evaluation, we've become guinea pigs for new paint and new cleaning solutions. Lovely.
I hope so, New Orleans. Knowing that the best cleaner for the job also doubles as a "refreshing" drink from the galley is scary when you think about it.

Fields.DialogueText: The military would never do something like... never mind. I just can't say it with a straight face.
We could always use a new germ fighter or two.
The Bug Juice? All that and it keeps the ‘scurvy' out of scurvy seadogs. You can't get much more multi-purpose than that...
*Wolf Whistle*
You called, Bosun?
NO Boat! XO wants you back at the flag bridge ASAP!
What's wrong?
It's Gin Fizz, Captain.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
That's not the only problem we have!
I came as soon as I could, Doc. What's the verdict?
Other than Gin Fizz is a sick cat, there's not much to tell. I think she's finally turned the corner though... she's holding down the last thing I gave her.
You think she'll make a recovery then?
She should be in the pink and ready for the crew to spoil her shamelessly again in no time.
That's a relief. Does New Orleans know?
I haven't seen NO Boat since Fizz was brought in, Captain.
I see. Does Fizz look at empty corners or anything?
Now that you mention it...
Then she probably does. You looked Fizz over when I brought her aboard, Doc. You didn't see anything wrong back then.
Nothing a bath and regular meals wouldn't solve. My best guess is that she got into something that disagreed with her.
But what would that be, Doc?

Fields.MenuText: Come on out, New Orleans. No one blames you for this.
She's your cat, New Orleans. There's no need to sneak around like this. You have every right to be here.
Fizz can see you and everyone is used to me talking to the bulkheads by now. Come on out, New Orleans!

Fields.DialogueText: I'm not sneaking, Capt'n. This is the sick bay and the last thing I want do is be in the way.
Sure, Capt'n. That's the least I can do for you, Doc. ... And not just for Fizz either, but for everything you do for everyone.
About what she got into...?
Take your pick, NO Boat. There's plenty of culprits: fresh paint, deck sludge, Bug Juice, official cleaning solutions, oil, aviation fuel, vermin, rations...
Point taken. Any suggestions?
Well, a lot of that we have around all the time and this wasn't Fizz's first Morgana battle either. Did she do anything unusual lately?
Fizz normally avoids the weather decks until things are squared away after a Morgana's been licked, but I saw her watching a gull from the signal bridge rail earlier before it was cleaned.
Then I would suggest you do as before and keep her indoors until the decks are clear and dry. If we're very lucky, she'll associate what she ate with getting sick and avoid it on her own.
My sea cabin is just off the the bridge. She can stay in there until things are squared away from now on.
She's welcome down here too. Call it shirking my job, but I'd rather you send me the ship's pet than a bunch of patients.
So much for boredom!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Take care now, little kitty... *sniffle*
You're letting Fizz go?
It certainly has been fun, but... as one free spirit to another, I can't in good conscience force her to stay. Besides, I know about our re-paint. She would go crazy in no time, all cooped up.
I understand. Trust me, I can think of more exciting things to do than watch your paint dry.
*wink* I do have to strip first. That can be plenty exciting...
But you sound like she's not coming back. Don't you want her to?
Of course, Capt'n!
Good, because she'll be back.
You sound so sure of that.

Fields.MenuText: How many cats do you know that have a whole heavy cruiser - Belle and all - wrapped around her paw? No cat that I know of would abandon that much territory without a fight.
Of course I am. I'm an excellent judge of character.
Why shouldn't I be? Fizz found you after all. Sorry to break it to you, but she's not your pet. You're her Belle.

Fields.DialogueText: Not many.
*grin* That's odd... you could've fooled me. So where's your gavel and robes, your Honor?
You do have a point there. She has seen through my camouflage every time...
@BATTLE
A wager?
Sure. Let's make a bet on Fizz.
I can't take a bet like that, Capt'n. That's as if I'm saying I hope Fizz won't come back, and that's the farthest from the truth as you can get.
That's fair. How about this then: if Fizz comes back before we finish re-painting your hull, I win. If she comes back before we leave port, you win.
And if she misses the boat?
We both lose, I suppose.
Stakes? What do I get if I win?
I was thinking about a fountain...
You mean an ice water fountain? Like the marble ones in the Old Absinthe House?
You might have to draw a picture of one for me, New Orleans. And that's if I lose.
Of course. So what do you get if I lose?

Fields.MenuText: I'd say surprise me, but I'm afraid you'd take that as a challenge.
Anything you can think of ... within reason.
A dog.

Fields.DialogueText: *grin* I certainly would... hee hee hee.
*wink* I can think of a reason for anything for everything, Capt'n.
*grin* Sure thing, Capt'n! A Saint Bernard with a keg on his collar is just what we need around here!
I have a souvenir postcard from the California Pacific International Expo in San Diego...
That sounds reasonable. ... What's the catch?
It's of the Zoro Garden Nudist Colony.
Thought so.
*grin* I know! How about a ship in a bottle?
A ship with a bottle gives a ship in a bottle? That sounds interesting enough.
Great! I have just the right bottle. It's not empty yet... want to help with that?
Certainly.
We'll pencil it in, Capt'n. This ain't exactly the climate for delicate work.
@BATTLE
I'm still unsure how this camouflage is supposed to make us look like an iceberg.
That's because you're standing on it. This is meant for a Morgana's eyes, which should be leagues away. From that distance, though...
Then it's going to take viewing from one of your floatplanes to know how effective it looks. So... why an iceberg?
Does the name Titanic ring any bells?
Icebergs may be rare in some oceans, but they still can be found just about anywhere.
They're big too, so it wouldn't be a stretch for a small convoy to be mistaken for the tip of a really huge one.
Dazzle camouflage I could understand. This... no Morgana is that gullible.
Give me one good reason why a Morgana wouldn't fall for it.

Fields.MenuText: Icebergs don't make over twenty knots against the flow of the current, New Orleans.
When would a ship of the International Naval Protection Force be asked to escort a giant chunk of floating ice? It's much too suspicious for a Morgana to ignore.
Smokestacks, New Orleans. Smokestacks.

Fields.DialogueText: So maybe we shut our engines down and drift into shooting range?
Maybe it'd make the Morganas curious enough to get closer, and then we blast em!
So we control our speed, then. Maybe we take it slow?
All I know for sure is that shooting and blasting are going to happen eventually.
Or right now! Battle stations, Capt'n!
@BATTLE
When you said something was missing on this iceberg... it was a snowman disguise?
*grin* I wasn't done with your penguin suit yet. But that's not all I added...
I noticed. What's that about?
There are all these blue swatches to simulate shadowy parts, right? So I thought I'd add some purple, to check how well Morganas can differentiate between the two.
If they can't, they won't be able to see my little message...
Don't give me "little", New Orleans. The whole thing is meant to be seen leagues away. What do these streaks spell out?
"BF, Kiss My Butt!"
I know, I know. "Kiss My Stern" would have been more accurate...
That's assuming the Bitch Fleet can read English.
That's assuming they can read at all, Capt'n. But it's in English on my port side and French on my starboard.
Insulting in two languages. How nice.
I think the lipstick mark on my fantail makes the message loud and clear for the illiterate, too.
@BATTLE
Well that was inconclusive. The Morganas certainly fit to be tied, but I couldn't tell by what.
That's what happens when you have too many variables.

Fields.MenuText: I think we can rule out the iceberg portion of the equation, though.
I could swear that she got angrier when you showed her your broadside. There may be something to your inflammatory messages after all.
You've met before, I think. All you probably need to do is show up to set her off.

Fields.DialogueText: *grin* I don't know... maybe they went through a bad hailstorm before and developed a passionate hate for it?
And she wasn't color blind.
Then it means I'm doing my job. I just wish it helped the sleeping beauties more than that.
Ready to go back to port?
Yup. We did leave in a hurry... and according to the Belle Network, there's a cat curled up on a piling from our berth that won't move. "Not for love nor catnip."
Told you.
I'm starting to worry about this new paint scheme, New Orleans...
You found a flaw in it, Capt'n?
Just the opposite actually. I know they're big and some spread over several surfaces, but ... it's just giant eyes. All over.
Well, we are running low on several colors of paint. And it works for birds, so...
Yes, I understand. But... who designed them?
I did. Why?
Because the harbormaster is getting calls. Lookouts on other berthed ships have chimed in, too.
All of them?
No... well, at least not all at the same time. Apparently, even if they're close enough to see how one particular eye isn't real, they just get the sensation from several new ones.
"It's as if ghosts are moving around and looking through different eyes to keep watching you." It's unnerving to observers.
That's good! Very good! If the Morganas are unnerved too, maybe the sleepwalkers of the fleet could actually chase them around for a change!
Oh, but if it pisses them off it would still work... we Belles could wear it instead, to draw them away...
Even some of your own crew are getting that sensation.
That's bad! Very bad! Why didn't you say so sooner?
Hold on. It's not everyone, just the freshest boots we have. Those of us who know you well are fine.

Fields.MenuText: It's kind of hard to get worked up about an unseen watcher when you do it all the time.
This ship isn't big enough for two spirits, New Orleans.
You're no doubt familiar with the many, many ways the old salts on this ship use our "haunted" status to get laughs and separate the crewmates from the squids.

Fields.DialogueText: I am the unseen watcher's unseen watcher, aren't I?
Thank you, Capt'n. I do my best.
Of course. I'm an active participant in most of them, Capt'n.
Still... I hate the thought of being scary to the people we're trying to protect.
We can cross that bridge when we come to it. If it does nothing to Morganas but make them laugh...
*grin* Let them. She who laughs last laughs best, and they won't be laughing last if they don't take me seriously.
@BATTLE
Capt'n, about my latest berth assignment...
Sorry, New Orleans. This is the closest I could get us to the wharf... and even that took arm-twisting. Consider this the price of a success.
Am I really that scary like this?
You, no. The crew, on the other hand...
I thought I'd noticed an increase in the shiners and fat lips lately... They're defending my honor.

Fields.MenuText: You have a fiercely loyal crew, that's for sure.
That's not something to be proud of. While I fully endorse lowering the boom on someone who is insulting you, there are other ways besides literally doing it.
Don't let it worry you. Doc tells me all injuries due to "fighting and biting" go to his corpsmen, so they're getting plenty of skill practice.

Fields.DialogueText: Anyone can collect a loyal body of crewmates, Capt'n. This just means that I'm fortunate enough to have more than a fair weather crew.
Oh, I agree, Capt'n. I'd rather not see anyone doing brig time - or worse - because they were defending my honor.
Ouch! I can't think of a more fitting punishment for a crime, but... ouch!
I guess there's hope for the sleepers yet.
About that...
Oh, no.
Sorry. It's been hard to get anyone else to test it, but the one or two Belle-less ships the lab convinced were switched back almost immediately.
When done poorly, the eye spots look so fake they don't do a damn thing.
When painted right, well... even your crew gets the sensation of being watched. They shrug it off because they know you.
Sailors on Belle-less ships don't have that kind of working relationship.
Oh, hell. The last thing I wanted to do was make sailors paranoid of their own ship. Any sleeping beauty that woke up to that would have every right to bite my head off!
... And that is why we test these things, New Orleans.
True. So, when is the repaint?
If the reaction in port is an issue for you, right away. If it's not, I thought we'd keep this one for a little while longer.
Oh?
I'd like to confirm how the average Morgana reacts to it before moving on to something new.
I want to try a few more times before you file it away in your bag of tricks.
*grin* Right. Because the ability to scare someone's pants off might come in handy someday.
Exactly.
@BATTLE
I think ‘fortune' has nothing to do with it, New Orleans. You just bring that out in people.
Capt'n? Who came up with the idea for this style?
The replacement for Stygian Fleet? Why?
I thought I knew all the paint variations the lab rats were toying with. This one's new... I didn't know it existed.
It's a new addition, I'm sure. What do you think?
I don't know. Pink? I know the school of thought that says flamingos are pink to blend in with sunrise, but I considered that school in need of remedial education.
So you think we should go with a different measure?
I didn't say that, Capt'n. I just wish I understood the method behind this madness.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe it's meant to test how drunk Morgans get. If they're used to ignoring pink elephants, maybe they'll ignore pink ships too.
Really? You're the usually the last Belle to need a reason to do something outrageous and silly.
Probably the only person who could explain would be the nut that thought of it.

Fields.DialogueText: That sounds like a Prohibitionist plot, if you ask me.
I'm more than willing to do outlandish tomfoolery at the drop of a hat... so somebody drop a hat!
You're probably right, Capt'n.
Seriously, it was my idea.
What!? Why?
I thought pink would be an absurd color. Something more approachable after your Stygian Fleet stint.
I see. My apologies, Capt'n. There is nothing inherently absurd about pink.
*grin* Pink polka dots, on the other hand...
@BATTLE
The designers in the lab thought it was reasonable enough...
If you insist...
So let me explain...
Behold... polka dots.
No doubt about it. There's a time to look impressive and a time to be ridiculous.
I'd say this is so ridiculous it's impressive.
*grin* You can say that again. I think I may have found what even I consider outlandish.
Until the next time.
Hee hee hee.
@BATTLE
Such art critics those Morganas were.
You know what they say, Capt'n... you can please some people all of the time and all people some of the time, but you can't please any of those rabid, lunatic dinghy-bats at any time.

Fields.MenuText: Not that you'd want to please one.
... Dinghy-bat?
I thought that saying was about trickery... that you can't fool all of the people all of the time.

Fields.DialogueText: *grin* That goes without saying.
Monster ships is too powerful a term for them, Morganas too mysterious and alluring and Bitch Fleet requires swearing like a sailor.
*grin* You could've fooled me.
*ALARM*
You wanted to see me in the wardroom, Capt'n, so here... what's this?
Fizz didn't return before we originally shipped out, so I lost our bet.
We did leave rather hastily, Capt'n. By rights, I lost the bet too, since we didn't quite finish the measure until we were out to sea.
I won't hold you to it. As for me, a bet is a bet.
So, can I unveil it?
Before you do, just remember that I said I couldn't make any promises.
That it would still be a fountain, it just might not like the marble ones I told you about. I remember, Capt'n.
Then go ahead.
Capt'n... that's... I'm astounded. Where did you find such a beautiful piece?
In the creative imagination of our Shipfitter's Mate. I took a page from you and the refurbished brass section of your jazz band...
That explains why everyone in Hull Maintenance has been so hush-hush lately. It's amazing what they can do with a little ingenuity! So, it's one of a kind?

Fields.MenuText: As unique as you are, New Orleans.
For now. I thought a matching fountain for condiments would lend symmetry to the other end of the counter and yes it's one of a kind!
Yes... Why? Is four spigots not enough?

Fields.DialogueText: I'll take that as a compliment, Capt'n!
*grin* Just checking.
*wink* Enough for the wardroom, here. But it looks so fantastic that I could just imagine one in your cabin, Capt'n...
It even has miniature signs to hang on the spigots?
Yes. The head steward assured me the lines could be cleared and cleaned easily.
Outside of a party, you shouldn't need more than one for water, so I thought the outermost could have milk for coffee most of the time.
This is a classy way to make it Blonde and Bitter. ... Throw in a slotted spoon and sugar, and you have a Blond and Sweet. I love it!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Keeping Fizz company until topside is clear, I see. It won't be too much longer.
Actually, she's keeping me company.
Is there a problem?
Nothing serious, Capt'n. I seem to have misplaced something, and I'm hoping she might be able to help me find it.

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I can help you look for it. Can I have a hint?
This again? You don't have to be cagey about it, New Orleans. If you think someone deserves a reward, just say so.
And not your crew of sharp-eyed snipes. That's unusual.

Fields.DialogueText: *wink* I think I left it next to my golden rivet...
I think everyone here deserves a reward. But no standouts this time.
I have them looking for something more important, Capt'n... the cork to my lunch! *dramatic flourish*
Seriously though, Capt'n. I'm not too worried. I'm sure it will turn up sooner or later...
If you say so. Still, whatever it is, don't let "later" go too long. We have our share of pranksters and I'd like to believe no one on board is a thief--
Which makes two of us, Capt'n.
Then good luck. I hope you find what you're looking for, New Orleans.
I don't know if I can... because I think I've lost my heart.
And if it was stolen, the culprit is you, Capt'n.
Nice try, New Orleans.
Then it's only fair you steal something from me right back. How about a kiss?
Nice try! I know this one is going to be freely given! *kiss*
Look sharp! Enemy contacts incoming!
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
